entry.title: Going forwards any deploys of JRuby 1.7.1, 1.7.2, and 1.7.3 will use OpenJDK 1.7.0_25.
entry.content: JRuby 1.7.1, 1.7.2, & 1.7.3 experience a libjffi-1.2.so warning if a they are used with a version OpenJDK 1.7.0_45 or later. Going forwards any deploys of JRuby 1.7.1, 1.7.2, and 1.7.3 will use OpenJDK 1.7.0_25.

entry.title: Platform API support for custom OAuth authorization expiration
entry.content: Clients can now specify a custom expiration for OAuth authorizations via the optional parameter expires_in.

entry.title: Rails 3 deploys now error out on failed `rake assets:precompile`
entry.content:
When deploying a Rails 3 app, if rake assets:precompile is detected as a valid rake task, and no asset manifest file is present (indicating that the task should be skipped), the precompile command is now expected to succeed. If it does not succeed the deploy process will exit, and the results of the assets:precompile task output to the screen for debugging.

If an asset pre-compilation fails on Heroku ensure that you can run it locally without error:

$ bundle exec rake assets:precompile RAILS_ENV=production RAILS_GROUPS=assets

See Troubleshooting Rails 3 asset precompilation for more information.

entry.title: Daily dyno restarts now have faster switchover
entry.content:
Dynos running on Heroku are cycled at least once per day. We are rolling out a change that makes the switch from old to new dyno smoother: Instead of waiting for the old dyno to shut down before starting a new one, Heroku now starts the new dyno as soon as the shutdown signal is sent to the old dyno. This change brings daily dyno restart behavior in line with general restart behavior and restart behavior when new app releases are deployed.

Read more about the Heroku Dyno Manager on Dev Center.

entry.title: Use of Heroku AWS security group and account id no longer recommended
entry.content:
Previously, Heroku recommended using our AWS security group and AWS account ID to grant apps access to other services running on AWS. Example use cases were:

  • Using AWS RDS with a Heroku app
  • Sending Heroku app logs to a Syslog server running on AWS EC2
  • Accessing other services running on AWS from Heroku apps

This approach is no longer recommended and the relevant documentation has been removed. Reasons for no longer recommending this include:

  • Cross-security grants don’t work with AWS VPC (which is now the default on AWS)
  • It’s not safe because it grants access to all apps running on Heroku, not just yours
  • Doesn’t work across AWS regions
  • Heroku may in the future run apps in a VPC or in a different region or use a different AWS account

If you are using Heroku with a AWS RDS database, we recommend using SSL to secure database connections. Find links and details in the Amazon RDS Dev Center article.

entry.title: JDK 7 Patch Level Bumped to u45
entry.content: The Java stack now uses OpenJDK 7u45 for apps that specify JDK 7. To use the updated JDK in your app push a new version to trigger a re-build: git push heroku master.

entry.title: JRuby 1.7.6 now available
entry.content:
The Ruby stack now supports JRuby 1.7.6 in 2.0.0 (experimental), 1.9.3, 1.8.7 mode.

To use JRuby 1.7.6 in Ruby 1.9.3 mode, add this to your Gemfile:

ruby '1.9.3', :engine => 'jruby', :engine_version => '1.7.6'

Adjust the ruby value depending on the mode you wish to use.

The JRuby release notes can be found here.

entry.title: Excluded Play 2.2 apps from Play 1.2.x app detection
entry.content: The app detection for Play 1.2.x has been improved to not include Play 2.2 apps that no longer contain a project/Build.scala files. Play 2.x apps are detected as and handled as Scala apps.

entry.title: Platform API dyno and formation `size` attributes are now strings
entry.content: The size attribute of dynos and formations is now taken and return as a string instead of an integer.

entry.title: Node.js release: v0.10.21 and v0.8.26
entry.content: Node.js versions 0.8.26 and 0.10.21 have been released and are now available on Heroku. They address a denial-of-service vulnerability in Node’s HTTP stack. For upgrade instructions, see https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/nodejs-support#versions

entry.title: Platform API has a new format for referencing resources
entry.content:
We’re changing the way resources are identified in requests to the Platform API: Instead of a nested object containing either the resource id (eg: "user":{"id":"01234..."}) or a human-friendly identifier (eg: "user":{"email":"username@example.com"}), you now have to supply a simple attribute containing either the id or the friendly identifier: "user":"01234..." or "user":"username@example.com".

The previous format will continue to work until Nov 4th. For more info please refer to this list of specific endpoints that are affected.

entry.title: Account confirmation retired
entry.content:
Account confirmation has been retired. All unconfirmed accounts with credit cards have been contacted and migrated.

Read more about account verification on Dev Center.

entry.title: Platform API collaborator management endpoints now require `write-protected` OAuth scope
entry.content: The platform API endpoints for collaborator management now require the write-protected OAuth scope to be accessed (previously, they only required write).

entry.title: Dyno restart policy
entry.content:
Restarts in the case of repeated dyno crashes now have exponential backoff. In the normal case of a long-running web or worker process getting an occasional crash, the dyno will be restarted without any intervention on your part. If a dyno crashes multiple times in a row, it will be restarted with exponentially increasing cool-off periods. If you push a new release to your app, the cool-off period will be reset.

Previously, the backoff policy was to restart dyno crashes every 10 minutes.

entry.title: JRuby 1.7.5 now available
entry.content:
The Ruby stack now supports JRuby 1.7.5 in 2.0.0 (experimental), 1.9.3, 1.8.7 mode.

To use JRuby 1.7.5 in Ruby 1.9.3 mode, add this to your Gemfile:

ruby '1.9.3', :engine => 'jruby', :engine_version => '1.7.5'

Adjust the ruby value depending on the mode you wish to use.

The JRuby release notes can be found here.

entry.title: Interrupt propagation for `git push`
entry.content: When pushing code to Heroku, you can now interrupt the build process by pressing Ctrl + C.

entry.title: Clojure apps upgraded to Leiningen 2.3.3
entry.content: Clojure apps will now use Leiningen 2.3.3 upon deploy. Read more about Clojure support.

entry.title: Play 2.x slugs exclude SBT compile-only artifacts
entry.content:
To reduce slug sizes, new builds of Play 2.x apps now exclude the following directories after compilation, as they are not required at runtime:

  • project/boot
  • target/scala-*
  • target/streams
  • target/resolution-cache

entry.title: Play 1.2.5.3 Support
entry.content: Support for Play Framework version 1.2.5.3 is now available. Read more: Heroku Play Framework Support

entry.title: WebSockets available in public beta
entry.content:
WebSockets are now supported on Heroku, as part of Heroku Labs. To enable WebSockets for your application run:

$ heroku labs:enable websockets -a myapp

Language specific WebSocket guides can be found for:

  • Node.js
  • Ruby
  • Python
  • Java

entry.title: EV SSL Certificates now in use for Heroku-owned applications
entry.content:
Heroku now uses Extended Validation SSL Certificates for most of our Heroku-owned applications. This allows you to tell at a glance if a URL belongs to Heroku itself, or whether it is some customer’s app running on the Heroku platform. This only applies to browser-facing apps (dashboard, www) not API-like things (api.heroku.com, Heroku Postgres backend services).

For more information, see EV SSL Certificates and Heroku-owned Applications in the Dev Center.

entry.title: Platform API "PATCH formations by type" endpoint now responds with single type
entry.content: The platform API’s PATCH /apps/:id/formation/:type endpoint now returns the serialized version of the single type that was patched rather than responding with the full list of all types.

entry.title: Node.js v0.10.20 Support
entry.content: Heroku now supports Node.js v0.10.20, which fixes some issues in last week’s 0.10.19 release. You can specify a version in the engines.node field of your app’s package.json file, e.g. 0.10.x.

entry.title: Heroku CLI v3.0.0 released replacing db:push/pull with pg:push/pull
entry.content:
A new version of the Heroku CLI is available that removes the db:push and db:pull commands, replacing them with pg:push and pg:pull. These new commands are faster and significantly more robust but no longer support non-Postgres databases. For help installing Postgres locally see local Postgres setup in Dev Center.

Detailed information on these new commands can be found in the pg:push and pg:pull section of the Heroku Postgres documentation.

Update your Toolbelt and push and pull your Postgres databases.

$ heroku update
Updating from 2.40.0... done

$ heroku pg:pull will::DATABASE_URL my_local_copy
pg_dump: reading schemas
pg_dump: reading user-defined tables
pg_dump: reading extensions
...

$ heroku pg:push my_local_copy will::RED
pg_dump: reading schemas
pg_dump: reading user-defined tables
pg_dump: reading extensions
...

entry.title: Dataclips improvements with clip forking and syntax highlighting
entry.content:
Newly forked Dataclips now add a “Fork of …” prefix by default to distinguish them from their parents.

Syntax highlighting has been improved to correctly handle Postgres specific syntax such as select $$dollar quoting$$;.
